visualization_prompt: Generate a heatmap showing color perception differences across vision types using color simulation techniques for color blindness
visualization_explanation: The dataset represents a 4x4 matrix with two categorical dimensions: base colors (nominal scale: Red, Blue, Yellow, Green) and vision types (ordinal scale: Normal vision to Tritanopia). Synthetic color codes were generated using established color blindness simulation algorithms, maintaining hue relationships while altering saturation/brightness to match respective vision deficiencies. Data quality is high due to controlled simulation parameters and discrete categorical bins. The heatmap visualization maximizes data-ink ratio by directly mapping color perception differences to color values, eliminating redundant legend elements through direct labeling. Cairo's principles of salience and discriminability are implemented through high-contrast color boundaries and categorical spacing. Color values follow WCAG 2.1 contrast guidelines (minimum 4.5:1 ratio) with systematic hue shifts: deuteranomalia shows red-green compression (Δh=+30°), protanopia exhibits red desaturation (ΔS=-40%), and tritanopia demonstrates blue-yellow inversion (ΔL=+20%).
